docs.text: vampires starts out almost in the style of a spaghetti western with an attack on a small homestead in new mexico .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the house has a nest of vampires and jack crow ( james woods ) is leading a team of vampire hunters in to clean them out .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: while the initial imagery is a little over-dramatic , it gives way to what is a fairly decent action sequence .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that is enough action to last us a while and we could , director john carpenter would let us , get to a story line .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but it is not very long and there is not much plot until the next big action scene .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: then there is only a bit more of plot before the next action scene after that .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the plot is kept to a minimum and the interesting ideas in the plot really get the short end .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: and that is something of a pity because the film , based on the book vampire$ by john steakley , gives us a myth for the origins of vampires and explains why vampires are so intertwined with religious imagery .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this could be an interesting departure from the standard vampire film , but carpenter decides to tell us about it rather than to show it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: what carpenter saves his serious screen time for a sequence of spectacular fights between hunters and vampires .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there is a lot of fighting and lots of gore .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: anything intriguing is kept to a minimum to so it does not get in the way of pleasing the action film fans .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this has not always been carpenter's style .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: his 1981 version of the thing has action but also challenges the viewer to do a little thinking about the film's central science fictional question .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: jack crow heads a vampire swat team , cleaning up nests of vampires with high-tech spears and crossbows .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in the early part of the film his team is wiped out by a particularly mean vampire valek ( thomas ian griffith ) who has been tipped off to who crow is .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: now crow team is gone and he is down to himself and his sidekick tony montoya ( daniel baldwin ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: to make matters worse , he does not know the people on his own side , tony and his backers , he can trust .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: meanwhile jack is sure the vampires are looking for something that must be hidden somewhere here in new mexico .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: if this is sounding like a very tired police corruption plot with a few obvious substitutions , that's exactly what it is .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the same story looks just as well with two partner cops looking for a gang of hood who are themselves looking for a packet of heroin .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but carpenter goes against a familiar principle of film : show people , don't tell them .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: just about everything in the plot other than the fights we are told about in the dialog and not shown .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: fundamental questions in the plot like where does crow get his funding , why are the vampires in new mexico--what do they want and why do they want it , what is the connection of the vampires and the catholic church , how did crow come to be a vampire hunter and why devote his life to it ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the answers to any of these questions could have been dramatized , but instead are revealed through dialog .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: now if all this was not bad enough , carpenter misuses the james wood persona .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: woods plays a particular sort of cool lowlife very well .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but carpenter leads off the film by having woods do some sergio-leone- style mythic posturing .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: while his crew prepares for an attack he stands staring fixedly through shades at the house that will be his target .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: woods does not work as a larger than life mythic hero .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that is not his style and it just does not work very well .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there are some simple things that carpenter should be looking for as director that he misses .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in one scene we are looking at a motel room with dead people on the floor .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: one female corpse is on the floor in front of a chair so that there is about an inch of daylight between her and the chair .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: as the actress breathes the gap widening and narrowing makes it obvious her arm is moving up and down .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: one also wonders how the existence of vampires is kept secret .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: these vampires do not maintain a low profile .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there are arguably logical flaws in the film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there is some question in my mind whether carpenter has a consistent policy on what effect bullets have on vampires .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it would take some rationalization to explain why in some scenes sunlight has a dramatic effect on vampires , yet in a scene toward the end a vampire can walk under a burned roof that lets him be swept by beams of sunlight .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i suspect that the book on which this film was based was better thought out .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: while i might recommend this film to an action audience i would say that what i look for in a vampire film vampires rates a 4 on the 0 to 10 scale and a 0 on the -4 to +4 scale .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: perhaps i will read the book .
docs.label: negative
